entry.title: 3... 2... 1... Start here!
entry.summary: WhatWelcome to this blog documenting my learning journey into the "cryptoverse", or…
entry.content:
What

Welcome to this blog documenting my learning journey into the "cryptoverse", or the rabbit hole that is blockchain security.

I will focus primarily on:

  • Blockchain security in general (blockchain or protocol agnostic)
  • Smart contract security & audits
  • Risks related to decentralized finance (DeFi)
  • Ethereum security & Ethereum virtual machine (EVM)
  • Etc.

Please make sure to use the tags to filter through the various subjects.

The more you know, the more you realize you don't know.

Why

There is currently an extreme shortage of knowledgeable security professionals in the job market, and I reckon the shortage in the field of blockchain security is even more pressing.

Since sharing is caring, I hope to inspire others with my (albeit nascent) knowledge, and information I have come across through my searches on the internet.¬†

I hope this blog helps you on your journey üôè

‚ÄúIn the land of the blind, the one-eyed man is king.‚Äù

By whom

Hello, I'm Rey Olson! Pleased to meet you üëã

Illustration by Justin Metz/Alamy via The Economist.

¬†

entry.title: yAcademy
entry.summary: Yearn Finance launched yAcademy (proposal launched in November 2020, pilot finished in…
entry.content:
Yearn Finance launched yAcademy (proposal launched in November 2020, pilot finished in July 2021).

What is yAcademy you ask? Here is a summary (from the original proposal):

We launch the yAcademy: a security wing tasked with auditing Yearn‚Äôs contracts, attracting and retaining top talent, and eventually generating revenue by expanding its auditing services to the ecosystem at large. Mission: audit Yearn contracts in a collaborative and semi-structured process. Administrative costs are kept near zero, as the tasks of advocacy, event organizing, educational curriculum are handled by our partners at Gitcoin and Status. The yAcademy is net positive from day one since money that would have otherwise been an operational expense given to auditing firms is now an investment that should pay back the principle immediately (in the form of audits of Yearn contracts) and generate revenue eventually (once the team has expanded to offer services to the ecosystem).

yAcademy will be operated as a joint venture by the yAcademy partners‚ÄîYearn (through the Multisig Council), Gitcoin, Status and member-auditors (including the first five auditors to join). The alignment can be seen in the following figure:

  • What is Yearn Finance? Check out this article: https://coincentral.com/what-is-yearn-finance/¬†
  • There exists a DAO (ReviewDAO) to engage security reviews from peers, but it seems dead (unless there is an active Discord, which I doubt, but I didn't check).
  • Immunefi is a DeFi bug bounty platform which has more success, but I'll cover this in a separate blog post.

entry.title: Gitcoin & KERNEL Fellowship
entry.summary: About Gitcoin We‚Äôre on a mission to build an internet that is…
entry.content:
About Gitcoin

We‚Äôre on a mission to build an internet that is open source, collaborative, and economically empowering.

We are creating community and infrastructure for Web 3 ‚Äî a diverse range of tools, technologies, and networks that enable people to work for the open internet.

By funding projects, building community, and making learning resources accessible, we are teaming up to create the digital public infrastructure of tomorrow.

KERNEL is an 8-week, invite-only program for top tech talent looking to build relationships, products, and companies in blockchain and Web 3. It is foremost a community initiative, supported by Gitcoin.

One of the sub-tracks available is the security track. Please note that they also have a free learning track üå± ‚ù§Ô∏è.

You can apply for the next block of participants here: https://apply.kernel.community/¬†

Syllabus of the security track:

  • Week 1 ‚Äî Web3 differences from traditional security (w/ Corey)

    • zero trust models everywhere
    • data responsibility is on the end user
    • ‚Äúthere is no castle‚Äù
    • pyramid of pain

  • Week 2 ‚Äî Automated Tooling (ToB / Dilligence)

    • what is automated tooling good for?
    • invariant definition
    • CI/CD
    • Tooling available

  • Week 3 ‚Äî Manual Review (ToB / Diligence)

    • why is manual review necessary when there is so much automated tooling available
      • architectural overview
      • intent
      • the human factor
    • risk assessment / threat modeling

  • Week 4 ‚Äî Process Quality (Rex)

    • the development process
    • preparing for an audit
    • documentation

  • Week 5 ‚Äî Org Security (Mehdi)

    • zero trust models
    • oversight
    • incident response
      • failure mode plans
    • red/blue teaming
    • education

  • Week 6 ‚Äî Monitoring / Alerting (OpenZeppelin)

    • CI/CD
    • Asset monitoring
      • on-chain
      • off-chain
  • ToB = Trail of Bits
  • Diligence = ConsenSys Diligence
  • Gitcoin is not the first organisation fostering growth in the crypto, but they are one of the most prolific in the area (or at least, it's a name I often see popping up, i.e. besides all the crypto venture capital companies üòè)

entry.title: Secureum Part 7: Audit Findings 101
entry.content:
Content

  1. Article on "Audit Findings 101":¬†https://secureum.substack.com/p/audit-findings-101
  2. YouTube videos on "Audit Findings 101":
    1. Block 1:¬†https://youtu.be/SromSImIpHE
    2. Block 2:¬†https://youtu.be/KLBi3Uyg0dY
    3. Block 3:¬†https://youtu.be/RUyED_6mkqg
    4. Block 4:¬†https://youtu.be/D1Uz0NvrqeU
    5. Block 5:¬†https://youtu.be/GX8Z0kRRi_I

Assignments

  1. Read the audit report along with the smart contracts to understand all the reported findings for Fei Protocol: https://consensys.net/diligence/audits/2021/01/fei-protocol
  2. Read the audit report along with the smart contracts to understand all the reported findings for Uniswap V3: https://github.com/Uniswap/uniswap-v3-core/blob/main/audits/tob/audit.pdf
  3. Read the audit report along with the smart contracts to understand all the reported findings for Chainlink: https://github.com/sigp/public-audits/blob/master/chainlink-1/review.pdf
  4. Read the audit report along with the smart contracts to understand all the reported findings for Opyn Gamma protocol: https://blog.openzeppelin.com/opyn-gamma-protocol-audit/
  5. Watch: OpenZeppelin tinchoabbate‚Äôs ‚ÄúSecure Development Series‚Äù: https://www.youtube.com/playlist?list=PLdJRkA9gCKOONBSlcifqLig_ZTyG_YLqz

Thoughts

¬†

entry.title: Capture The Flag (CTF)
entry.summary: Capture the Flag (CTF) in cyber security is an exercise in which…
entry.content:
Capture the Flag (CTF) in cyber security is an exercise in which "flags" are secretly hidden in purposefully-vulnerable programs or websites. CTF's are often organised as a live competition where participants steal flags either from other competitors (attack/defense-style CTFs) or from the organizers (jeopardy-style challenges). Several variations exist, including hiding flags in vulnerable blockchain contracts for others to exploit and/or abuse: thus enter blockchain (security) CTF's! These challenges are based on the traditional outdoor sport of the same name. (~ loosely copied from Wikipedia and extended by myself)

Here's a list to some well-known Ethereum CTF challenges. I might do a more detailed write-up of some of these to brush up my writing skills üòÖ. If you get stuck: walkthroughs are easy to find through your favourite search engine!

  • Ethernaut
  • Capture The Ether
  • Damn Vulnerable DeFi
  • Paradigm CTF

There exist other, lesser-known "pop-up" CTF challenges, e.g. see samczsun's post on Twitter with the corresponding pinball machine contract üïπ:

https://rinkeby.etherscan.io/address/0xffb9205c84d0b209c215212a3cdfc50bf1cfb0e0#code¬†

Photo by Sigmund on Unsplash

entry.title: Secureum Part 6: Audit Techniques & Tools 101
entry.content:
Content

  1. Article on "Audit Techniques & Tools 101":¬†https://secureum.substack.com/p/audit-techniques-and-tools-101
  2. YouTube videos on "Audit Techniques & Tools 101":
    1. Block 1:¬†https://youtu.be/M0C7z3TE5Go
    2. Block 2:¬†https://youtu.be/QstpNY1IuqM
    3. Block 3:¬†https://youtu.be/QmD2bJUe140
    4. Block 4:¬†https://youtu.be/jZ81ebDJVe0
    5. Block 5:¬†https://youtu.be/dgITqd3mkDk

Assignments

  1. Read:
    1. How to Prepare for a Smart Contract Audit
    2. What is a Security Audit, When You Should Get One, and How to Prepare
    3. 246 Findings From our Smart Contract Audits: An Executive Summary
  2. Run MythX (Use promotion code: SECUREUM2021) on Fei Protocol contracts and analyze the reported findings: https://github.com/fei-protocol/fei-protocol-core/tree/master/contracts
  3. Run Slither on Uniswap V3 contracts and analyze the reported findings: https://github.com/Uniswap/uniswap-v3-core/tree/main/contracts
  4. Watch ‚ÄúThe Evolution of Smart Contract Security‚Äù by Dan Guido, Trail of Bits: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=fOkQuNzVn_Q
  5. Attempt Paradigm CTF: https://github.com/paradigm-operations/paradigm-ctf-2021

Thoughts

¬†

entry.title: Ethereum EVM illustrated
entry.summary: The book Mastering Ethereum does a great job explaining most important Ethereum…
entry.content:
The book Mastering Ethereum does a great job explaining most important Ethereum aspects, but it often helps to have a 'visual aid' to truly understand how things work.

Enter Ethereum EVM illustrated, a document dating back to 2018 that really helps you understand most of these abstract concepts:

For additional reading, see also: https://ethereum.org/en/developers/docs/evm/ & especially the section #further-reading üìï

Illustration by @alexdndz on Reshot

entry.title: Everybody is winging it, all the time.
entry.summary: I probably suffer a tiny bit from imposter syndrome, so I find…
entry.content:
I probably suffer a tiny bit from imposter syndrome, so I find it hard to commit myself to consistently write articles (however minimal they might even be) for this blog. But then again: sucking at something is the first step to being sort of good at something. So here it goes, below you can find the list of resources I have come across on my adventures on the world wide web.

Some of these links I can already scratch from the list ‚úîÔ∏èüòä.

I am still thinking about:

  1. How to best structure posts. One aspect is that alot of these resources are also on other's guides (e.g. see Introduction to smart contract security and hacking), but I don't think it's a big issue. Each of these items is worthy of a blog post, as there is alot of content to cover.
  2. I reckon the Publii theme I've chosen is not the most sensible one for blogging, but I'll see how it goes... üôà

General

  • https://kernel.community/module-0/ (‚úîÔ∏è->article)
  • https://github.com/trufflesuite/ganache-cli-archive¬†
  • https://ethereum.org/en/developers/learning-tools/¬†
  • https://matterlabs.notion.site/matterlabs/Matter-Labs-Team-Handbook-43342b471fe14f05b2baf250cb7c7a02¬†
  • https://medium.com/matter-labs/evaluating-ethereum-l2-scaling-solutions-a-comparison-framework-b6b2f410f955¬†
  • https://cryptodevhub.io/wiki/blockchain-development-tutorial¬†
  • ETH.BUILD: https://www.youtube.com/playlist?list=PLJz1HruEnenCXH7KW7wBCEBnBLOVkiqIi¬†
  • The sorry state of DeFi security: https://youtu.be/6iJC-1meyYU¬†

Security

  • https://media.consensys.net/time-sure-does-fly-ed4518792679#.r5e4xnbph¬†
  • https://www.damnvulnerabledefi.xyz/¬†(‚úîÔ∏è->article)
  • https://docs.openzeppelin.com/contracts/4.x/¬†
  • https://docs.openzeppelin.com/learn/developing-smart-contracts¬†
  • https://docs.soliditylang.org/en/latest/security-considerations.html#¬†
  • https://github.com/guylando/KnowledgeLists/blob/master/EthereumSmartContracts.md¬†https://dasp.co/#item-1¬†
  • https://cryptoservices.github.io/¬†
  • https://github.com/sigp/solidity-security-blog/blob/master/README.md¬†
  • https://consensys.github.io/smart-contract-best-practices/known_attacks/¬†
  • https://consensys.github.io/smart-contract-best-practices/recommendations/¬†
  • https://consensys.net/blog/developers/the-smart-contract-security-mindset/¬†
  • https://consensys.net/blog/blockchain-development/ethereum-smart-contract-security-recommendations/¬†
  • https://consensys.net/blog/developers/solidity-best-practices-for-smart-contract-security/¬†
  • https://blog.openzeppelin.com/the-hitchhikers-guide-to-smart-contracts-in-ethereum-848f08001f05/¬†
  • https://research.nccgroup.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/03/NCC-Group-Whitepaper-Coinbugs.pdf¬†
  • https://github.com/PeterBorah/smart-contract-security-examples/issues/3¬†
  • https://medium.com/@peterborah/we-need-fault-tolerant-smart-contracts-ec1b56596dbc¬†
  • https://blog.ethereum.org/2016/06/19/thinking-smart-contract-security/¬†
  • https://blog.ethereum.org/category/security/¬†
  • https://hackingdistributed.com/2020/03/11/flash-loans/¬† +¬† https://hackingdistributed.com/2016/07/13/reentrancy-woes/¬†
  • https://media.consensys.net/time-sure-does-fly-ed4518792679¬†
  • https://cryptoconsortium.github.io/CCSS/¬†
  • https://www.pentestpartners.com/security-blog/blockchain-implementation-security-a-hardening-how-to/¬†
  • https://matterlabs.notion.site/Best-Practices-69868a3105e04ba0b5e15e94ea27bfc6¬†
  • https://consensys.github.io/smart-contract-best-practices/¬†
  • https://github.com/fravoll/solidity-patterns¬†
  • https://secureum.substack.com/p/smart-contract-security-101-secureum¬†
  • https://chain.link/bootcamp/bootcamp-2021-on-demand¬† (see chapter regarding smart contract security)¬†
  • https://secureum.substack.com/p/smart-contract-security-resources (‚úîÔ∏è->article)
  • https://github.com/securing/SCSVS¬†
  • https://github.com/SmartContractSecurity/SWC-registry¬†
  • https://www.notonlyowner.com/learn/intro-security-hacking-smart-contracts-ethereum ¬†(‚úîÔ∏è->article)
  • https://github.com/tintinweb/smart-contract-sanctuary¬†
  • https://yacademy.substack.com/p/yacademy-newsletter-1 (‚úîÔ∏è->article)
  • https://swcregistry.io/¬†
  • https://rinkeby.etherscan.io/address/0xffb9205c84d0b209c215212a3cdfc50bf1cfb0e0#code¬† + https://twitter.com/samczsun/status/1451236190917701636 (‚úîÔ∏è->article)
  • https://github.com/KadenZipfel/smart-contract-attack-vectors¬†
  • https://github.com/Rari-Capital/solcurity¬†
  • https://medium.com/immunefi/the-web3-security-revolution-ec33ea7a85f8¬†

¬†

EVM¬†
  • https://eth.wiki/en/concepts/evm/ethereum-virtual-machine-(evm)-awesome-list¬†
  • https://takenobu-hs.github.io/downloads/ethereum_evm_illustrated.pdf (‚úîÔ∏è->article)
  • https://blog.qtum.org/diving-into-the-ethereum-vm-6e8d5d2f3c30¬†
  • https://consensys.net/blog/blockchain-explained/¬†
  • https://consensys.net/blog/blockchain-explained/want-to-really-understand-blockchain-you-need-to-understand-state/¬†
  • https://media.consensys.net/ever-wonder-how-merkle-trees-work-c2f8b7100ed3¬†

'Everybody is winging it, all the time', I came across this saying a couple of years ago and it resonated with me. It still does, after all these years. A quick search brought me back to the Hacker News post discussing the (seemingly original) Guardian article "Everyone is totally just winging it, all the time".

Photo by David Pupaza on Unsplash.

entry.title: Secureum Bootcamp Part 4: Security Pitfalls & Best Practices 101

entry.content:
Content

  1. Article on "Security Pitfalls & Best Practices 101":¬†https://secureum.substack.com/p/security-pitfalls-and-best-practices-101
  2. YouTube videos on "Security Pitfalls & Best Practices 101":
    1. Block 1:¬†https://youtu.be/OOzyoaYIw2k
    2. Block 2:¬†https://youtu.be/fgXuHaZDenU
    3. Block 3:¬†https://youtu.be/YVewx1xVROE
    4. Block 4:¬†https://youtu.be/byA3MLLiKMM
    5. Block 5:¬†https://youtu.be/vyWLO5Dlg50

Assignments

  1. Explore the SWC Registry list and test cases: https://swcregistry.io/
  2. Watch ‚ÄúIntro to Security First Development‚Äù by Gon√ßalo S√°, ConsenSys Diligence: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=72K57I9yvyI
  3. Watch ‚ÄúProtect your Crypto and Avoid Getting Hacked‚Äù by Mehdi Zerouali, Sigma Prime: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=L2DRC6PjTgk
  4. Watch ‚ÄúDeFi Security: With So Many Hacks, Will It Ever Be Safe?‚Äù on Unchained Podcast with Dan Guido (Trail of Bits) and Taylor Monahan (MyCrypto): https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=Sc5fZ-Wprx8
  5. Attempt CTF: https://capturetheether.com/

Thoughts

  • Update on 7 November 2021, the evening at the deadline before the quiz for this part closes. I'm really having trouble to set aside enough hours to study (read the articles, watch the video's, do the assignments, ...). Family life is quite consuming (and takes priority üòÖ) i.e. I only have a couple of hours available in the evenings (and then not even every day / night), so it's pretty hard. Anyway, let's keep going at it!
